content:
You don't have any test cases that evaluate to a negative answer, only validators. It would be good to swap some of these around so that clashers can debug issues in the clash, rather than getting 100% on the test cases and then submitting and getting 77% on validators.

The second 'medium' example and the last 'hard' example are the two that currently evaluate to negatives.

Negatives are an important edge case, because you might naively just have a while loop that keeps looking for "+-*/" and doesn't stop until they are all gone, but of course for negative results, this loop won't stop because the "-" can't be simplified with more loops.

I suggest you swap the two "medium" tests so that the negative one becomes a test case and the positive one becomes a validator.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good and (somewhat) simple clash to remember the CS basics.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A little hard for a new person to code in less than 15min

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i do it before

You should mention that when rounding to two decimal places, if the decimal places are empty,  you fill them with 0.

I also feel like that this is a bit too hard for 15 minutes, It might fit better for a puzzle, but this is way too hard for a clash. You would need a very good logic understanding for this, and it might take some time for people to figure it out, and then to code it would just take more then 15 minutes.

I think that it would suit better if this was changed to a puzzle instead of an clash.

Goal section
* Please format "2 + 3", "2 3 +", "5.0 1.0 2.0 + 4.0 * + 3.0 -", "DIVISION BY ZERO" and "INVALID EXPRESSION" as {{constants}} and remove the quotation marks.

* 2nd paragraph: Please format +, -, * and / as {{constants}}.

* The order of operations is irrelevant when an expression is written in RPN (not even your code shows anything to implement the stated order). Please delete the 3rd paragraph.

* 5.0 + ((1.0 + 2.0) * 4.0 + 3.0) is wrong.

* Please change "higher centesimal 10^-2" to "2 decimal places".

Input section
* Please change "Ligne" to "Line".

Constraints section
* Please remove the 2nd and 3rd constraints as they are not constraints on the possible test cases.

Cases
* While Goal section mentions the rounding requirement, it does not mention how many decimal places should be shown in the output. I would suggest you to revise the cases and your solution to always show 2 decimal places for simplicity. Otherwise, please state the relevant requirement in Goal section.

* Please add at least 1 more pair of cases where the rounding requirement is actually tested (currently NONE of the cases requires any rounding; all results are exact results).

Thanks.

Thanks for your detailed comment. I have made the suggested changes. 
Let me know if there are any other aspects that still need improvement.
Your feedback is greatly appreciated.

Thank you for your feedback.
Regarding the format of the results, I made the corrections.
Regarding the difficulty of the exercise, I believe it is fine and can be completed in less than 10 minutes, even without extensive coding experience. I will see if there are others who find it difficult, and if that's the case, I will consider transforming it into a puzzle.

A similar but simpler clash exists:
https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/344369f32c06be2509613f06a34226ef751b9

The current contribution deals with floats and an additional situation (invalid expression); that's why I still consider this not too similar enough to be considered a duplicate.

However, it won't be a good idea to turn this into a puzzle, because there are existing RPN puzzles already:
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/reverse-polish-notation
https://www.codingame.com/training/medium/the-polish-dictionary

I agree that this will be difficult to complete in the time frame. 
For approval, the benchmark is it should be completable in 5mins
Is there a way to simplify it? Maybe constraining the input to be a valid expression so no need to worry about div by zero or invalid?

I'm not sure how to make this clash easier without making it too similar to the clash that 5DN1L linked to. The main differences right now are float numbers (instead of int) and differing between DIVISION_BY_ZERO and INVALID EXPRESSION (instead of both being NaN).
